IIDX - Chartspowered by Bootstrap

  • d3 Charts

Charts

Highcharts Charts

Series Charts

A series chart contains a single value for each point along the primary axis. Multiple series charts sharing an axis can be shown together to allow visual comparisons.

The following series chart examples share this core configuration: average monthly temperature (a series) for two locations.

var seriesConfig = {
  title: { text: 'Monthly Average Temperature' },
  subtitle: { text: 'Source: <a href="http://WorldClimate.com">WorldClimate.com</a>' },
  series: [{
    name: 'Tokyo',
    data: [7.0, 6.9, 9.5, 14.5, 18.4, 21.5, 25.2, 26.5, 23.3, 18.3, 13.9, 9.6]
  }, {
    name: 'London',
    data: [3.9, 4.2, 5.7, 8.5, 11.9, 15.2, 17.0, 16.6, 14.2, 10.3, 6.6, 4.8]
  }],
  xAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Month'
    },
    categories: ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec']
  },
  yAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Temperature (Â°C)'
    }
  }
};

See highcharts.com for information about highcharts configuration.

Example
Description

Bar Chart; a series chart with horizontal bars showing data values. Note that the yAxis specified in the configuration is the horizontal axis (X and Y axes are switched from normal usage.)

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-bar" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.bar('chart-bar', seriesConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts
Example
Description

Stacked Bar Chart; a series chart with stacked horizontal bars showing data values. Stacked charts are useful to visualize cumulative totals among series. Note that the yAxis specified in the configuration is the horizontal axis (X and Y axes are switched from normal usage.)

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-bar-stacked" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.barStacked('chart-bar-stacked', seriesConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts
Example
Description

Column Chart; a series chart with vertical bars showing data values.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-column" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.column('chart-column', seriesConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts

Description

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-column-stacked" class="chart"></div>

     charts.columnStacked('chart-column-stacked', seriesConfig);

Example
Description

Area Chart. A series chart connecting data values to display as a single shape. Multiple series will overlap.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-area" class="chart"></div>

Script:

  $(function() {
     charts.area('chart-area', seriesConfig);
  });
});

  • charts

Markup:

Script:

  $(function() {
     charts.areaStacked('chart-area-stacked', seriesConfig);
  });

Line Chart. A series chart drawing connecting lines between data points in a series.

Usage

<div id="chart-line" class="chart"></div>

  $(function() {
     charts.line('chart-line', seriesConfig);
  });
});

Scatter Plot

Scatter plots display data with two salient dimenions. Multiple series are differentiated by the color or symbol used for points in the series.

The scatter plot example uses this core configuration:

var scatterConfig = {
  title: {
    text: 'Height Versus Weight of 507 Individuals by Gender'
  },
  subtitle: {
    text: 'Source: Heinz  2003'
  },
  xAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Height (cm)'
    }
  },
  yAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Weight (kg)'
    }
  },
  tooltip: {
    formatter: function() {
        return ''+ this.x +' cm, '+ this.y +' kg';
    }
  },
  // data redacted; view source for full configuration
  series: [{
    name: 'Female',
    data: [â¦]
  }, {
    name: 'Male',
    data: [â¦]
  }]
};

See highcharts.com for information about highcharts configuration.

Example
Description

Scatter Chart, displaying data series with two dimensions.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-scatter" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.pie('chart-scatter', scatterConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts

Radial Charts

Radial charts divide a circle according to the value of each data point in a series. Values will be normalized (they do not have to add up to 100%.)

The following charts share this core configuration:

var pieConfig = {
  series: [{
      data: [['Jan', 29.9], ['Feb', 71.5], ['Mar', 106.4], ['Apr', 129.2], ['May', 144.0], ['Jun', 176.0], ['Jul', 135.6], ['Aug', 148.5], ['Sep', 216.4], ['Oct', 194.1], ['Nov', 95.6], ['Dec', 54.4]]
  }]
};

See highcharts.com for information about highcharts configuration.

Example
Description

Pie Chart.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-pie" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.pie('chart-pie', seriesConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts
Example
Description

Donut Chart. A Pie Chart with a hole in the middle.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-donut" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.donut('chart-donut', pieConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts
Dark Theme
Description

The IIDS includes a dark theme for highcharts. Note that only one theme type can be used on a page at a time. The last theme set will apply to all charts on a page. By default charts will use the "light" theme.

Usage: 
      define([
        'charts/theme-dark',
        'highstock'
        ], function (theme) {
          'use strict';
          Highcharts.setOptions(theme);
        });
Script Requirements:
  • charts/js/charts/theme-dark

Highcharts Variants

Example
Description

Highstock Chart, showing a line chart with an x-axis navigator and zoom controls.

Note This example loads local JSON so might not work in Chrome or IE. To preview use Firefox or a web server.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-stock" class="chart"></div>

Script:


// define highcharts config
var stockConfig = {
    title: { text: 'Stock Prices' },
    series: [],
    rangeSelector: {
      selected: 1
    },
    yAxis: {
      labels: {
        formatter: function() {
          return (this.value > 0 ? '+' : '') + this.value + '%';
        }
      },
      title: {
        text: 'Change'
      }
    }
};

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
    // load data files asynchronously
    $.when(
      $.getJSON('../assets/data/aapl.json'),
      $.getJSON('../assets/data/goog.json'),
      $.getJSON('../assets/data/msft.json')
    ).done(function(aapl, goog, msft) {
      // data is first argument of each call
      stockConfig.series.push({name:'AAPL', data:aapl[0]});
      stockConfig.series.push({name:'GOOG', data:goog[0]});
      stockConfig.series.push({name:'MSFT', data:msft[0]});
      // create stock chart
      charts.stock('chart-stock', stockConfig);
    });
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts

Series Charts

The following chart shares this core configuration with the other Series examples:

var seriesConfigVariant = {
  title: { text: 'Monthly Average Temperature' },
  subtitle: { text: 'Source: <a href="http://WorldClimate.com">WorldClimate.com</a>' },
  series: [{
    name: 'Tokyo',
    data: [7.0, 6.9, 9.5, 14.5, 18.4, 21.5, 25.2, 26.5, 23.3, 18.3, 13.9, 9.6]
  }, {
    name: 'London',
    data: [3.9, 4.2, 5.7, 8.5, 11.9, 15.2, 17.0, 16.6, 14.2, 10.3, 6.6, 4.8]
  }],
  xAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Month'
    },
    categories: ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec']
  },
  yAxis: {
    title: {
      text: 'Temperature (Â°C)'
    }
  }
};

See highcharts.com for information about highcharts configuration.

Example
Description

Line Chart with a label for each data point.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-line-with-labels" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
     charts.line('chart-line-with-labels', $.extend(true, {
       plotOptions: {
         line: {
           dataLabels: {
             enabled: true
           }
         }
       }
     }, seriesConfigVariant));
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts

Spiderweb Charts

Spiderweb charts are used to compare between three and nine variables.

The following charts share this core configuration:

var spiderConfig = {
  xAxis: {
    categories: ['KPI1', 'KPI2', 'KPI3', 'KPI4', 'KPI5', 'KPI6', 'KPI7', 'KPI8', 'KPI9'],
  },
  yAxis: {
    max: 80000,
  },
  series: [{
    name: 'Average',
    data: [50000, 54000, 52000, 51000, 56000, 54000, 57000, 53000, 49000],
  },{
    name: 'Previous',
    data: [32000, 36000, 60000, 51000, 46000, 60000, 37000, 60000, 59000],
  },{
    name: 'Custom Service Coord',
    data: [30000, 39000, 62000, 41000, 36000, 64000, 27000, 63000, 49000],
  }],
};

See highcharts.com for information about highcharts configuration.

Example
Description

A spiderweb chart showing nine values.

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-spiderweb" class="chart"></div>

Script:

require( ['jquery', 'charts'], function($, charts) {
  $(function() {
    chartsMore.spiderweb('chart-spiderweb', spiderConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts
Example
Description

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-spiderweb-tiny" class="chart"></div>

Script:

  $(function() {
     chartsMore.spiderwebTiny('chart-spiderweb-tiny', spiderConfig);
  });
});

  • charts

Description

Spiderweb Comparison

Usage

Markup:

<div id="chart-spiderweb-comparison" class="chart"></div>

  $(function() {
     chartsMore.spiderwebComparison('chart-spiderweb-comparison', spiderConfig);
  });
});
Script Requirements:
  • charts

d3 Charts

Standard chart types are defined with simple declarative markup, and rendered as SVG graphics with d3.

To invoke visualizations, first use a <div></div> element with the data-visualization attribute set to the appropriate visualization type. Additional data- attributes are used by each type to declare the values for rendering.

<div data-visualization="bar"></div>

To initialize the visualization, first require the declarative visualizations module to import the necessary code libraries.

require(['declarative-visualizations'], function(visualizations) {
  ...
});

In the require callback, invoke the visualization method on each of the matched elements and apply any additional functionality as needed.

$('div[data-visualization="gauge"]').each(function(i, element) {
  var gauge = visualizations.gauge(element);
});

By changing the data- attributes on the tag and then calling update you can redraw the visualization.

var gauge = visualizations.gauge(element);

// ... change data-* attributes ...

gauge.update();
Example
Description

A bar chart graphic.

note: the look and functionality of this component will be deprecated in favor of the meter component below

Usage
<div data-visualization="bar" data-max="5000" data-value="3965.20" data-threshold="1000"></div>

HTML5 data- attributes are used to control parameters of the graphic.

Name Description
data-duration Animation speed in milliseconds of visualization for initial render and subsequent updates. (optional)
data-visualization Type of graphic. Should be "bar".
data-max Maximum value.
data-min Minimum value. Defaults to 0. (optional)
data-target Target URL for optional JSON source. Will ignore other `data-` attributes if specified. (optional)
data-threshold Threshold value. Defines the position of the white marker on the visualization. (optional)
data-value Current value. Defines the size of the colored area.
Script Requirements:
  • declarative-visualizations/js/declarative-visualizations.js
Example
Description

A meter chart graphic.

Usage
<div data-visualization="meter" data-max="230" data-value="20" data-threshold="180" data-markers='[["H", 212], ["L", 32]]' data-unit="°F" ></div>

HTML5 data- attributes are used to control parameters of the graphic.

Name Description
data-duration Animation speed in milliseconds of visualization for initial render and subsequent updates. (optional)
data-visualization Type of graphic. Should be "bar".
data-max Maximum value.
data-min Minimum value. Defaults to 0. (optional)
data-target Target URL for optional JSON source. Will ignore other `data-` attributes if specified. (optional)
data-threshold Threshold value. Defines the position of the black marker on the visualization. (optional)
data-value Current value. Defines the size of the colored area.
data-unit A unit of measurement label paired with the data-value .(optional)
data-markers Data for the setpoint markers. A JSON array, where each element is an array of [label, value].

CSS classes can be be added to the meter's container div to change the fill color.

Class Description
none
.notice
.warning
.danger
Script Requirements:
  • declarative-visualizations/js/declarative-visualizations.js
Example
Description

A donut chart graphic.

Usage
<div data-visualization="donut" data-source='[["Capital Allocation", 19.5], ["Operations & Maintenance", 10.2], ["Fuel", 70.3]]'></div>

HTML5 data- attributes are used to control parameters of the graphic.

Name Description
data-visualization Type of graphic. Should be "donut".
data-duration Animation speed in milliseconds of visualization for initial render and subsequent updates. (optional)
data-labelhidden Boolean toggle for visibility of labels. Defaults to false. (optional)
data-source Data for the visualization. A JSON array, where each element is an array of [label, value].
data-target Target URL for optional JSON source. Will ignore other `data-` attributes if specified. (optional)
Script Requirements:
  • declarative-visualizations/js/declarative-visualizations.js
Example
Description

A semicircular gauge graphic.

note: the look and functionality of this component will be deprecated in favor of the speedometer component below

Usage
<div data-visualization="gauge" class="chart1" data-value="23" data-max="100" data-threshold="50" data-label-min="0" data-label-max="16mm"></div>

HTML5 data- attributes are used to control parameters of the graphic.

Name Description
class Controls the chart color. One of chart1, chart2, chart3, or chart4.
data-visualization Type of graphic. Should be "gauge".
data-duration Animation speed in milliseconds of visualization for initial render and subsequent updates. (optional)
data-label-max Text for the label at the right end of the gauge. (optional)
data-label-min Text for the label at the left end of the gauge. (optional)
data-max Maximum value.
data-min Minimum value. Defaults to 0. (optional)
data-target Target URL for optional JSON source. Will ignore other `data-` attributes if specified. (optional)
data-threshold Threshold value. Defines the position of the white marker on the visualization. (optional)
data-value Current value. Defines the position of the needle.
Script Requirements:
  • declarative-visualizations/js/declarative-visualizations.js
Example
Description

A speedometer chart graphic.

Usage
<div data-visualization="speedometer" data-max="100" data-value="60" data-threshold="70" </div>

HTML5 data- attributes are used to control parameters of the graphic.

Name Description
data-duration Animation speed in milliseconds of visualization for initial render and subsequent updates. (optional)
data-visualization Type of graphic. Should be "speedometer".
data-max Maximum value.
data-min Minimum value. Defaults to 0. (optional)
data-target Target URL for optional JSON source. Will ignore other `data-` attributes if specified. (optional)
data-threshold Threshold value. Defines the position of the black marker on the visualization. (optional)
data-value Current value. Defines the size of the colored area.

CSS classes can be be added to the meter's container div to change the fill color.

Class Description
none
.notice
.warning
.danger
Script Requirements:
  • declarative-visualizations/js/declarative-visualizations.js

d3 Calendar Chart

Description

Calendar view can be used to provide an overview of time series data by visualizing the data points as colored cells per day. Days are arranged into columns by row, then grouped by month and years. Values are then quantized into a given color scale.

Example

Layout

Year Range

Tooltip

Legend

Brushing

Color

Event

Events
Usage

Markup:

<div id="myCalendar" style="height: 600px"></div>

Script:

require(['jquery', 'declarative-visualizations'], function ($, visualizations) {
  var options = {
    valueField: "CHI",
    dateField: "DATE"
  };
  var myCalendar = visualizations.calendar('#myCalendar', options);
  $.getJSON("../assets/data/calendar.json", function(data){
    myCalendar.update(data);
  });
}

Options:

Options can be passed via HTML5 data- attributes or JavaScript. For data attributes, append the option name to data-, as in data-dateField="".

Name Type Default Description
dateField string '' Required. The date field name for each data record, determining where the data record is positioned in the calendar view.
valueField string '' Required. The value field name for each data recrod, describing which variable of the data record is color-coded in the calendar view.
yearRange array null The start and stop year to show in the calendar view. Leave null or empty for automatic update from data.
tooltip boolean true Enable the mouseover tooltip on each day. Set to false to disable.
legend boolean true Show the legend. Set to false to hide.
brushing boolean false Enable the brushing behavior on the calendar view. Set to false to disable.
layout string 'vertical' Set the layout of the calendar view - vertical | horizontal | horizontal-vertical
colorTheme string "orange" The color theme to fill each day cell - "blue" | "orange" | "purple" | "red" | "green" | "yellow"
colorSteps number | array 3 If colorSteps is number, it specifies the number of colors to fill each day cell. If colorSteps is an array of numbers, it specifies a list of value thresholds to fill each day cell.
tweenDuration number 500 Set the animation transition duration in milliseconds.
margin object {top: 30, right: 30, bottom: 30, left: 30} Set the margin of the calendar view. Make sure to give enough margin for the labels.
